guide.title: Gentoo Weekly Newsletter
guide.subtitle: 16 July 2007
guide.abstract: This is the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter for the week of 16 July 2007.

section.title: Welcome back from the GWN staff

body.p: Gentoo's GWN staff is pleased to be back after a short break. We would like to thank everyone that continued to submit news and ideas to the GWN and to everyone that offered to help. Unfortunately, sometimes life gets in the way of volunteer time, but we are back. There will be some changes done to how we publish the GWN which should make it quicker for us to create, hopefully allowing us to publish on schedule.

As always, the GWN is looking for submissions from the community. If you have something Gentoo-related that you would like to share with the GWN readers, send it to gwn-feedback@gentoo.org and we'll add it to a future edition of the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter.

section.title: Gentoo Council and Trustee nominations open

body.p: Nominations are being taken for the Gentoo Council, the body which governs the direction of Gentoo's software releases and repositories, and the Gentoo Foundation's Board of Trustees. The Council is a technical body where the Trustees are a legal body. New nominees are given on the gentoo-dev mailing list. The nominations are tracked at /path/to/xml.

Diego PettenC2 announced on his blog his progress with PAM. Some time ago there was a discussion about moving sys-apps/cracklib out of the system packages set as it was not a necessary package. However sys-apps/cracklib is no longer in the system, if you used PAM you couldn't remove it as sys-libs/pam considered it as a necessary dependecy. Diego has committed a revision bump for sys-libs/pam in ~arch that makes cracklib optional, controlled by the cracklib USE flag.

Estimate emerge times with a handy tool called genlop. You can analyze the emerge.log to find out how long a package took to compile. Example: # genlop -nt kdelibs Tue May 8 18:26:59 2007 >>> kde-base/kdelibs-3.5.6-r8 merge time: 38 minutes and 6 seconds.
This information can be used to estimate how long an update would take. The tool can be used to calculate the emerge time for a variety of packets (like an update world) by calling it this way: Example: # emerge -uDp world | genlop -p These are the pretended packages: (this may take a while; wait...) [ebuild U ] app-office/openoffice-2.2.1 [2.2.0] [ebuild U ] media-libs/netpbm-10.39.0 [10.37.0] Estimated update time: 5 hours, 50 minutes.
Now what if you have a new packet that you didn't have installed? Example: you want to install fluxbox on a pc without previous X installed: # emerge -p fluxbox | genlop -p ... [ebuild N ] x11-libs/libXmu-1.0.3 USE="-debug -ipv6" [ebuild N ] x11-apps/xmessage-1.0.1 USE="-debug -xprint" ... !!! Error: couldn't get previous merge of xmessage; skipping... !!! Error: couldn't get previous merge of fluxbox; skipping... ... !!! Error: fluxbox never merged; estimated time unknown.
Genlop will only reference the packages it knows. If you use the -q option (genlop version >= 0.30.7), an online database running on gentoo.linuxhowtos.org is queried for compile times based on users with an identical cpu like yours.
Above query results in: emerge -p fluxbox | genlop -p -q These are the pretended packages: (this may take a while; wait...) ... Estimated update time: 38 minutes.
Voila ;) The times are not 100% accurate; it does not respect USE flags or memory speed, hdd speed a.s.o. But as the times get averaged over different users, these factors become less important.

Marcus Hanwell this year represented Gentoo KDE team at akademy. aKademy is the annual meeting for KDE users and developers. This year it was held in Glasgow, Scotland. Marcus spoke Sunday about Gentoo & KDE. If you want to know more about his talk, you can see the slides link="http://blog.cryos.net/uploads/MDHanwell-aKademy2007.pdf">here and download a video here. He was satisfied with aKademy; the event was a good opportunity to learn a lot and enjoy some really great talks. He also spoke about KDE and scientific applications on 14th July 2007 at the Gentoo UK Conference.

In a full-page review of Gentoo Linux 2007.0 in the August 2007 issue of Linux Format, the reviewer, Neil Bothwick, was so impressed with the new release that he awarded the distribution 9 points out of ten. From the article: "The upside is that you have great control over what is installed. It is this control, rather than the ability to use insane compiler flags govern which features are enabled in the software you install, and by disabling features you don't need, you can save space, reduce dependencies, shorten program load times and even lessen your susceptibility to security holes. Building your own kernel is also made easy by the 'genkernel' tool used by the installer, or you can use this to configure your kernel manually. Portage contains almost 12,000 packages, so you won't be short of software." The author concludes: "If you want more control over your system and are prepared to make the extra effort, Gentoo could be just what you are looking for."

Techgage did a nice little review of the Gentoo 2007.0 release. It points out some of the major changes and also lists a couple hangups with the new installer. There's also a couple nice screenshots comparing the livecd vs the livedvd. http://techgage.com/article/gentoo_20070/

section.title: Linux Weekly News discusses Package management

body.p: In the July 5 edition of the Linux Weekly News (http://lwn.net/Articles/240081/), Gentoo developer Donnie Berkholz (dberkholz) wrote an article title Package management in Gentoo Linux. The article compares the three available package managers and includes a brief overview of their features, as well as mentioning PMS and EAPI.

The Gentoo community uses Bugzilla (bugs.gentoo.org) to record and track bugs, notifications, suggestions and other interactions with the development team. Between 08 July 2007 and 15 July 2007, activity on the site has resulted in:

ul.li: 533 new bugs during this period
349 bugs closed or resolved during this period
20 previously closed bugs were reopened this period
104 closed as NEEDINFO/WONTFIX/CANTFIX/INVALID/UPSTREAM during this period
82 bugs marked as duplicates during this period

body.p: Of the 9816 currently open bugs: 12 are labeled 'blocker', 109 are labeled 'critical', and 350 are labeled 'major'.
The developers and teams who have closed the most bugs during this period are:

ul.li: Gentoo's Team for Core System packages, with 33 closed bugs
Portage team, with 14 closed bugs
Gentoo Linux Gnome Desktop Team, with 11 closed bugs
Gentoo Security, with 10 closed bugs
Gentoo KDE team, with 9 closed bugs
Gentoo Toolchain Maintainers, with 8 closed bugs
Saleem Abdulrasool, with 8 closed bugs

body.p: The GWN is staffed by volunteers and members of the community who submit ideas and articles. If you are interested in writing for the GWN, have feedback on an article that we have posted, or just have an idea or article that you would like to submit to the GWN, please send us your feedback and help make the GWN better.
